for the price, I can't complain. The functionality is still a bit lacking for my taste and I had to work way too hard to get alexa to work with foreign time zones as I travel a lot. If you dont go and research how to do it you are stuck with calendars and alarms/reminders that don't work.    I would love to see the functionally extended to a voice to text or voice to email dictation function.    all in all a fun purchase and I would recommend it for the curious.

Think I have a dumb Alexa. She does tell jokes.  She gives me weather for another nearby city.  She's up to date on news and sports but has a hard time recognizing questions.    The reason for the 4 stars is because she does recognize my kindle and my prime playlists and will make a suggestion if I ask for other music.  Other than that, her "knowledge" is very limited.

Amazing product for under $50!  Very easy to set up and was able to connect it to my smart hub in one minute.  Controlling the lights by voice is cool.    Alexia does a much better job with commands or questions than Siri.  Ask for a recepie and it gives the ingredients and pushes the recepie to alexia app.  You can customize a sports update or weather.

Ok I am a big fan of what Amazon has done with both the Dot and Echo. I have one of each. They are smart little devices and if you invest a little time you will be surprised at what they can do. I gave one of these to a family member as well, such that they can get weather, be amused and also listen to music.

The Dot works great for music and weather in my kids' rooms.  They ask the time, set alarms for school/events, set timer for homework and I even heard them ask the weather report when they were getting ready in the morning.  Cheaper than most alarm clocks and easy for them to use.  Other than as a lazy radio, I'm not sure we would use it for anything else.  I do NOT want to order deals and more stuff with it, so we avoid those features.

Sometimes it wants to work and sometimes it seems to find excuses not to do what you ask it to do.  Right now it seems very limited what it can do but l think it will be the way of the future so l want to get use to it now.  Programming it can be tricky and difficult and then other times it went smoothly.

Alexa and I have been together a few days now, and things couldn't be better lol. I purchased the dot because it would fit better in my room as i try to make the room then house smarter. Setup wss easy and fairly quick. Alexa is awesome. Great to have and i cannot wait to discover more that this little echo does.

nice idea, but out of 6 that I purchased 1, was bad, that's a 17% failure rate.  The problem is that I bought for Xmas and gave to people who did set up right away, and I lost the opportunity to return, too late.  At first, it synced off and on, but got progressively worse.  If you get one TEST it right away.

This item is amazing! Alexa turns my Hue lights on and off, adjusts my nest thermostat, and even makes me laugh when I ask for a joke. Many people comment about the speaker not being very loud but I can hear her just fine in the surrounding rooms. I've had the dot for about three months and have played around with the functions on a regular basis, yet I feel that I'm still just scratching the surface of what this device can do.

Definitely not as flexible as Google home in terms of responding. Quit working after 3 days of use.  If you're thinking about whether getting this or Google home, I suggest you getting the later. Google home has much better potential then Alexa, and doesn't look cheap

My Google phone answers more questions. It's basically a toy. Fun, but useless. It's constantly disconnecting from my wifi and then telling me it can't find connected devices. I'm constantly reconfiguring every dang one in my house. That's just not convenient. However, my Jeopardy skills are getting better.

I love alexa. Amazon needs to start to sell cell phones because alexa is so much better than Siri. Just make sure that you actually articulate what you are trying to say otherwise she won't understand. A bit annoying that in order to turn your house into a smart home for her the switches and plugs cost $50 each, but worth it!

This is so much fun!  I love having the weather, music, and shopping list right at my voice tips.  Haha.  We hooked it up to a boss sound dock for some extra kick and it's just awesome.  What a great product, shopping list has to be my favorite option.  We are still learning but continue to enjoy everyday.

We have had a great experience with the Echo Dot so far.  I would definitely recommend it to anyone that plans on connecting to a nice bluetooth speaker or an A/V system because the speaker that is built in works okay to hear Alexa talk but when playing music it sounds like a tin can.  Fortunately for us we connected it to our surround sound receiver as an analog input via a 3.5mm to RCA cable.  I installed the Logitech Harmony skill (the red one) and connected the dot to my Harmony Hub and it has been working out really well.  The one drawback of not using the Dot's built in speaker is you need to have whatever system you are using for sound turned on and the volume to a good level - the Harmony Hub resolves this issue for me.  I programmed an activity I named "Sound" through the harmony app that switches my receiver on and changes to the correct audio input.  Now I say "Alexa, Turn on the Sound" and I can hear the Echo Dot on my surround sound system.  Or the kid's favorite "Alexa, Turn on the Xbox" which is usually followed by me saying "Alexa, Tell Harmony to Mute".    The Echo Dot also works Really well with the Phillips Hue hub and was very simple to set up.  Being able to walk in to my dark home and say "Alexa, turn on the Living Room Light" and have the light immediately turn on is awesome.  And so far - it works without fail!

Love this little device. I've been using the Amazon Fire Line for a while now and I have to say this Amazon Echo Dot is by far the most useful device. I could CONFIRM that you DO NOT need the Amazon Echo in order to work this Amazon Echo Dot. Setup for this device was a breeze. Just plug in the power cable to the unit and download the Amazon Alexa app and you're all done. Not only can you use this device to play music but you could use it to set alarms. The microphone on this unit is really good and it can hear you from across the room. I've used this frequently when I cook, it makes it so easy to set multiple times for certain foods. It even tells you the recipe for the meals too. This little device is small and sleek and does not take up space at all. We use this device to check the weather every morning before heading out. There is so many things this little device could do, we hooked up our Nest Thermostat to this and control our heating unit all through voice command. This little unit carries LOTS of potential, there are so many other things we connected this unit to, we are currently controlling our house lights with this all by saying "Alexa, Living room on" and the TV by "Alexa turn on TV". Although the living room lights and TV functionality requires an additional add on equipment I still think this is pretty cool and is one step away from Jarvis from Iron Man.

Literally the best little nightstand device. Thought it was mostly hype but decided to get one because its so damn cheap. I hooked it up to some old speakers and use it as a podcast and music player and alarm clock. It also hooked up to my smart home devices pretty simply. I show it off to everyone who will pay attention.

Initially, I fell in love with this device.  When I tried to interface with Insteon, (the original reason for the purchase), I had difficulties. There was no specific information of how to speak to Alexa to get the lights to respond. I spent an enormous time reading how to setup Insteon and Alexa after it was set up. The information that I was looking for was not available.  I am still not quite sure what works. I have finally figured out what to name scenes to get Alexa to control the lights.  There were no instructions that really helped. Lots of instructions that provided no useful syntax information. Secondly, I have a whole house audio system.  I would have bought multiple Echo Dots if I could use one of them for the output of all of them.  I will cancel my new subscription to the music in favor of my Airport Extreme. From my iPhone I can choose any of the airport extremes to output to. One of them is in a closet with my whole house audio system.  I figured I could have 4 ethos in the house and could have them all output to a single source. Nope, so, I really have no reason to own more than 1 echo dot. It will only be used in my bedroom hooked up to a separate Speaker System. Can I use my phone as a control, no. Can I use my Music Subscription on more than one Dot, no. Does the remote work without pressing a button, no.  So, if your system was designed with flexibility I would own 4 Echo Dots and a music subscription.  Instead I will never own more than one Dot and no Music Subscription.

The Amazon Echo Dot is a LOT of FUN. I love asking questions, and hearing silly replies. My favorite is to ask Alexa to play music by genre. I learn new artist that I hadnâ€™t known before. I will never use the ordering ability as I am not likely to order laundry detergent, paper towels, or mouth wash. Kind of a waste here.  My biggest issue is, if you want to listen to music, which is the Dotâ€™s forte, you HAVE to pay for a Amazon Prime account. I am not going to do this.  The gift I bought for my wife, an Echo Dot, is limited to answering questions that may or may not be in the Alexa database, and she is denied any ability to play music other than what she already paid for on Amazon. I wanted to keep my Amazon account separate from my wifeâ€™s, but due to that, she canâ€™t get anything from Amazon, even though I bought this for her and set it up under her profile.  So, the Dot is cool, but it is designed to make money for Amazon. (Duh) The problem is, if you buy one, and expect to get what is promised on the page, you also HAVE TO BUY a Prime account. So, Amazon pretends that there is no subscription fee for using a Dot, or any other Tap or Echo device, but bear in mind that it is not something worth buying if you are not the Prime Account Holder. It is so limited that it is worthless.  Google does NOT require all of this paid membership stuff.

Does exactly the same thing that the largest Echo does. Only the speaker size is different. The quality is still adequate for music. If you are a music quality snob then you still have the option of hooking it up to your stereo or whatever. I have purchased both the Echo and the Dot. The Dot is a real bang for the buck compared to the original Echo. The Tap (middle-sized) is the one that is slightly different than the original Echo or the Dot. I don't have a Tap, but I hear it has a docking/charging station; the advantage of that is that it can run unplugged using batteries; the Echo and Dot don't have that feature.    Cons:  Most of the special features like ordering a Dominos pizza are not as cool as you'd think. They are very limited in their flexibility/options.  These are typically add-on installations you ask Alexa to setup for you or you can setup using your android device or Kindle.  Alexa typically has problems answering anything other than the most basic questions.    Pros:  Listen to music (you can "pause", "resume", ); ask about weather, calendar events, basic facts, wikipedia topics; setup reminders, timers, shopping list, calendar events. Alexa can read books too, but I haven't mastered that; I'm not sure if you need Kindle Unlimited for that or not.  My nephews' favorite add-on app: "Ask for a Fart".

What can I add that hasn't been said by 10K reviewers?  I was really touched by the reviewer who got the Dot for his relative with MS; just beautiful.  I think the simplicity of the whole platform is what impresses me the most.  All you need is the four or five Post-It-sized instructional pages to get up and running.  I didn't do any voice training, and yet Alexa hears me and responds from two rooms away!  The $3.99 Music Unlimited deal per month with a free trial is perhaps an even better deal than the incredibly cheap price of the unit itself.  I shared it with some friends over Christmas and they all want one.  Truly an amazing piece of hardware/software integration.  Congratulations Amazon!

So far the Dot has done what it has been asked of. It recognizes my voice commands perfectly, but I have not fully utilized all the functionality as of yet. My one concern is the power adapter is an issue. Why could it not be either a slim design or a right angle to it. Putting this behind a dresser or bed causes the USB cable to bend. Is there a compatible Power Adapter that can be purchased? I would have given this product 5 stars if it wasn't for this.

Love, love, love my echo dot! The set up was extremely easy for the dot, and is exactly what I was looking for! I originally was unsure if I actually needed the echo dot, but I am so glad I decided to try it it! I bought the dot to use with my Nest thermostat and Philips Hue lights. The set up of the dot with these two systems only took 5 minutes max, and it works perfectly. Now I just tell Alexa to turn my thermostat down or up, and she does it no problem! The same with the Philips Hue lights. On top of that, I did not even know half of the other things Alexa can do and how easier some things can be thanks to this product! Instead of trying to remember what groceries I needed when shopping, I now just tell Alexa to add something to my shopping list at the moment I realize I need to buy more! This has helped reduce those "I forget.." trips back to the grocery store!!! Additionally, she can set timers or alarms for whatever reason, tell you the weather, update you on what you have planned on your calendar for that day, and SO MUCH MORE!!! I found the dot so helpful, that I even purchased a second one for the bedroom. She even reads a bedtime story to my 4 year old son at night, which he just finds so funny because the main character of the story is him! Overall, this is a GREAT product and a must for those looking to help make daily life a little bit more easy!

I love my Amazon Echo. I use it as an alarm clock and to turn my lights on and off. I hated walking to the bed with out the lights on, or having to get up because I forgot to turn them off. This is the sole perpose I bought the device. And it works wonderfully. I like to play music on it when I clean too. I bought everyone an echo for Christmas. My brother's review was. "I like, it I love it, I'll use it, I won't even try to sell it."

While the Echo Dot has improved my living experiences with its connectivity, there are some shortfalls that have prevented me from rating it higher. For one, the answering capabilities are severly lacking and Alexa struggles to answer even the basic questions like "When did Lost boys come out in theaters?" or "Who sings X song"    It's other downfall is its lag. Sometimes I'll ask it to turn off lights and will get a response almost immediately, but other times it will just blank or take a minute to trigger the lights.    Currently it's best feature is playing music through bluetooth. Always great for doing chores or getting ready for work. If the answering mechanism was better it'd get 5 stars, and it's definitely worth having for the price, but it still doesn't beat out google in searches

I've been looking for programming info that is paper based for Alexa & haven't found much of anything at amazon.  Kindle / electronic versions are plentiful but they just don't work too well when reading outside.  Short of doing screen prints of the electronic stuff, is there anything out there??  What am I missing?

I am enjoying my Dot and still learning what all it will do.  My only complaint is that sometimes it cannot answer what I feel is a simple question such as "Alexa, what is the 5th largest city in the Untied States"? She did not know.  Other than things like that, it's fun and useful to have around.

I like things quiet, but dot is way too quiet.. dot volume 10 is equal to Alexa volume 3, it is truly meant for a very small area like a bedroom    Need more name selections to wake it.  Needs to have the ring on top like Alexa, to control volume. The little volume buttons are annoying to try to hit the right one without looking.  Sometimes you have to try to wake it multiple times be it does what you ask.    Alexa (I have both) is far better.

Love this! The dot takes up less space and does everything the echo does. I've not explored everything it does, but listening to music, getting news briefs, getting the temperature outside, traffic, listening to radio stations all over the world, and so many other things is great. I look forward to new innovations as they are offered.

UPDATE TO REVIEW BELOW:  I have 3 of these set up in my house.  I've already had to exchange one because it quit working.  Now 2 of the other 3 all of a sudden can NEVER hear you - you have to yell at it, whereas before they all worked just fine.  ALSO, I ask/tell it to do something, like turn off a light, and it gives me an answer that is totally unrelated to anything even close to the words I've said.  I'm beginning to think maybe I should try that other one of these things that are out there by another company because these are not holding up.  ALSO, out of the blue I am simply sitting on my couch BY MYSELF surfing the net, and all of a sudden she starts talking for no reason whatsoever.  I do not have the tv on; I'm not talking to myself; so WTF!  I'm becoming less and less enamored with this product, and I've bought about 10 of them - 3 for myself, 2 for my boyfriend and the others I've given out for gifts or plan to (Christmas is almost here).  I normally don't rag on something on here BUT I've bought enough of these that they better not all start messing up, like 2 of my 3 are already doing.  Who wants to have to yell at something for it to respond - AND OH, just so you know, I'm standing with 6' of it - I'm not 50' away.  RIGHT NEXT TO IT and I get NOTHING.  Then I yell, and all of a sudden the stupid thing responds.  Did I mention I was ANNOYED!!!    I received my Echos timely and packaged well.  I am in LOVE with this little thing.  It works perfectly for me so far.  I have had a time or 2 when it simply would spin and not respond, but not enough to cause me to want to return it. I have one in my living room and one in my bedroom.  While it does reach out, for me, I don't want to have to yell to it from a distance.  Also, it connected to my Samsung bluetooth soundbar instantly (even though my speaker is not on the "approved" list you see here on Amazon).  It has come in so handy numerous times, like asking a quick question I have without having to pull out the tablet or phone to look it up; I have intergrated my google calendar so it will tell me what's on the schedule for the day or week.  I have also integrated the music from my Samsung S7 and it plays all my music as soon as I ask it to.  I have it hooked up to my Hue lights, and it works great from Alexa's standpoint - the Hue lights are a hit or miss as they often keep losing the connection to the bridge - even with the light in the same room as the router.  If this doesn't stop, they'll be going back because at $200 for my Hue kit, these things should not keep losing a connection and becoming undiscoverable - BUT, that has nothing to do with the Alexa.  If you don't have one of these, I highly recommend it.  It is handy as can be and ONLY $49.  What a dream gadget.  MY ONE SUGGESTION IS THIS THOUGH.  IT IS AN AMAZON DEVICE SO WHY DOESN'T IT HAVE A SKILL TO TURN ON OUR AMAZON FIRESTICK!!!

Worth it just to have my grocery list available at all times and to turn my bedroom light on before I even enter the room. My husband loves it because he can add items to it while I'm grocery shopping and doesn't have to call or text me. My granddaughter loves it because she has a partner to quiz her on subjects she learning in school--state capitals and US Presidents.

This device is sooo disappointing!  It rarely answers anything I can easily just say "Ok Google" on my phone and find an automated response.  I have even added all apps I found useful and it is just a pain in the ass to get then to work since you have to remember all these special command syntax in order to activate the app you want information from.  I wanted it mainly so we could do things like...ask movie or tv show information, look up facts and other things.  And above all....I wanted to be able to control lights with it.  Now I have to be honest in saying I have yet to buy the corresponding light bulbs or light switches for them to work with Alexa because they are so expensive...but frankly I would highly recommend buying Google Home over this piece of crap!  Sorry Amazon...I love you guys...but this device needs a major overhaul!!!!

Doesn't understand a thing you re saying if you have music playing in the background. Even at moderate volume...  However, I have thrown this thing against the wall at least 6 times now because it has been so disappointedly useless - and yet it still works. One star for usefulness plus two extra stars for built quality...

My grandson lives in a dorm and he and his roommate love it. Along with the Bluetooth speaker I sent him along with it, they listen to all their favorite music. As an alarm clock, it is unsurpassed. They also use it easily order pizza delivered to their dorm. Every college student needs one of these.

All-New Echo Dot (2nd Generation) - White    My wife's a technophobe - I had to actually work to get a smartphone into her hands.  Now that she's learned to use it though, and voice recognition, wow - I can't pry it out of her fingers!  Why would I mention this in the Dot II review?  The dot is another such piece of technology.    You might not want to learn the new skills to 'talk to' it, but once you do, you just love it!    Please note, Amazon sometimes offers the dot at a 1/4 price reduction if you order it WITH A DOT.  Don't buy more than one even if you want one in each room.  Wait til you get the first one then say "Alexa order another Echo Dot, second generation".  Or "Alexa, what are your deals".    you can get more skills here:  https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss_2?url=search-alias%3Dalexa-skills&field-keywords=alexa    AND Alexa has holiday promotions going on now (Dec 13, 2016) here:  https://www.amazon.com/Alexas-G/b?ie=UTF8&node=14655536011    We've got one on the main floor paired to a Bose speaker, and I'm waiting for the deal to order another to pair with the media room TV soundbar.    (I wonder if I can teach Alexa how to control the TV and soundbar on her own???)  No more finding the rermote - just "Alexa, turn on Netflix" would be nice!

So, we have been wanting Echo for a while.  We have other Amazon products in our house, a Fire TV, two Fire sticks, and a couple Kindles.  Since my old radio alarm clock was dying I decided that I would replace it with a dot, and it is wonderful.  I have it play me classical music to help me get to sleep and Alexa will play it on a sleep timer when asked.  I can set daily alarms, so no longer do I need to set and unset the alarm every morning.  She can run multiple alarms.  Also you can change the sound of the alarm, this is nice because after a while my alarm noise will start being like nails on the chalk board after a while.  Since she is in the bedroom where I get dressed she can give me a briefing of headline news from CNN and weather so I know how to dress for the day.  I do plan on getting Wemo switches for some of the lights in my house that I shut off before going to bed to link up, especially my bed side light, which my wife has forced on me as a job to shut off at night, so now I can give it to Alexa.  Never figured the bedroom would be a good place for Alexa but she works well there.  The little puck fits into the contemporary styling of our room.  One complaint about using Dot as an alarm clock, it has no face so you have to ask the time.  This is bad if you are the first one to wake you might not know the time, so it is hard to tell if you should roll over and go back to sleep, or get up.  Dot is easy to setup at least, and I am planning on more.  So, I would say I am happy with my purchase.

I have one of the original Echoes -- bought it sight unseen when Amazon offered it to a few Prime customers for $99. I'd never give it up. Bought two Dots for our house and love them.    PROS: The mini-jack lets you use your own external speakers, unlike the Echo. It just works! It's a less costly version of the Echo.  CONS: There's no ring on the top you can turn to control volume like on the Echo -- I really love that Echo feature. But the buttons you get instead aren't bad.    Some find this product confusing. It does exactly what the Echo does for less. It has its own speaker, but not as big or good as the Echo's. But it's still good enough. On the upside, you can attach it to any speakers or amp you want using a mini jack and cable.    If you still don't understand what Echo and Dot are all about, JUST BUY ONE! Get the Dot. You'll love it. I have one in the bathroom. I listen to the news while shaving, music while in the shower, check the weather report, and play a round of Jeopardy with Alexa every day. I also make lists of things I need to do while I'm still in the bathroom.    We now have one Echo in the kitchen, and a Dot in each of two bathrooms. We love Alexa! Haven't even tried using the "home controls" features with lights, etc yet -- but we will.    Amazon has a real winner here!

5 stars for the incredible value and innovation of this system.  Similar to Siri and Google, but it's much more functional and designed to work with other devices in your home.  Play music, set timers, alarms, control lights & thermostat, ask questions, get information and install specific 'skills' which act like voice activated apps.  For this stage in the game, it's pretty darn clever and it's going to continue to improve.  Amazing work Amazon!    Wish list for future updates:  - Conversation mode.  When I'm testing the limits of what Alexa can understand, it gets old saying 'Alexa' every time I have a new question to ask.  It would be easier to say 'Alexa, start conversation mode' and then everything I said afterward would be recognized.  - Answers to more questions.  I'm already very impressed by how much I can get away with asking, but there's still a lot to be learned.  Amazon isn't a search engine so they are at a disadvantage, but somehow they will have to continue to make strides in this department to stay competitive.  - More interactive.  This sort of goes back to my 'conversation mode' suggestion but I imagine more difficult to implement.  It would mean asking me followup questions or some other interactive responsiveness.  Maybe I've been watching too many tv shows about AI...but hey, a guy can dream right

This thing is nice, but its just gimmicky. I think it has a future, but we kind of got tired of it after a few weeks. Theres only so many things you can ask it and it gets old when it doesn't know how to do things because you didn't say them a particular way. I know voice AI is the future, but I would wait unless you are a tech person.

I love my echo dot...works great with the Alexa app and I can set grocery lists, get weather, ask sports questions and game times.  Best of all, I was able to connect to a Wifi light bulb from the Alexa app and now am able to tell Echo to turn my lights on and off.    You are also able to create groups of lights and name them for the different parts of your house.    This thing can also play music for you from Spotify, Amazon Music, etc and the speaker is surprisingly good and loud as well for its small size!    Very happy with this purchase!

Not sure how I really feel about this product yet. You have to constantly repeat yourself, half the time she doesn't understand what you're saying, or she doesn't have an answer. You have to "download" skills and then say to activate them every time. Not as simple as I thought it would be. Too many open concern and at the same time when she does work, it's pretty cool.

Warning: you may have a desire to replace all your light switches with Smart switches and put one of these in every room. Maybe one day...    When you have 3 little girls that rarely do what you ask them to, Alexa is a dream. I use her to turn off the Christmas lights paired to a TP-link smart outlet. Also, with Amazon Music Unlimited she plays anything I was to hear. When not paired to a speaker, you can hear her just fine, although I mostly have her Bluetooth connected to a portable Bose speaker. I much prefer the Dot over the big Echo as you can pair her with any speaker you want, and she's much easier to move around the house if you want to bring her someplace else. She can hear surprisingly well even from far distances as long as she has a clear-ish line of sight even with a lot of other background noise.    My only complaint is I wish she did more. I constantly find myself asking questions that she doesn't know the answer such as, "What channel is the Wisconsin Badgers playing on tonight?" Using a Nexus 5x and saying OK Google, usually brings up what I need as the first result, but it doesn't say it back to me. I am a bit curious if Google Home is better at answering quick questions, but I chose the Dot since it was much cheaper and integrates with Amazon Music. Hopefully Echo's get smarter as time goes on.

Received my first six pack of Echo dots, one for each of the kids and older grandchildren for Christmas and of course one for me.  Was first introduced to the taller Alexa at my cousins house and was impressed.  But the price was a little out of range and when I saw the Echo dot and read the reviews I couldn't stop myself especially at this price. For the price it is an outstanding value.  Easy to set up and I learn more about it each day.  In fact waiting for another six pack to be delivered because I decided to give two to each household plus one each to the older (10 and above) grandchildren.  Which is perfect becauseChristmas shopping almost done and I think I got the "hot" item for the year.  Excited they will continue to add new features to the Echo.  I almost feel like. I need to say "good morning" and "goodnight" to it each day.  I did have some problems getting my calendar synced with it but had prompt live instant help from representative who gave outstanding service and we finally figured out my email account was different for each item.  I most definitely would recommend buying from Amazon instead of third party just for their outstanding support. For a little chuckle, the other night when I was messing with the Alexa (Echo) app in another room, I was checking out what books it could read to me and didn't realize when I tested one book the Echo had started reading it...when I went into the room where Echo was ... there it was still reading the book...must have been a good book.

The big pluses for this compared to devices from other vendors are (1) he wider support for 3rd party apps and devices  (2) more attractive price.  At less than half the price of competing units and only $50 (even less on sale) you're not making a huge purchase here even if you only use it for a year or so.  And if you have a connected home or use some supported apps like OurGroceries you can start using it now.    A big minus is that the artificial intelligence from Amazon just isn't where the competition is in terms of quality.  Ask Alexa "What is the best way to reheat turkey?" or "what is the Amazon stock price?", to give but 2 examples, and Alexa can not answer.  Try this on your smartphone with Siri or Google and you get answers. And that's the rub.  Once you have a device like this you want to just speak and get answers instead of reaching for your phone.    You can extend the functionality of the device by enabling "skills", pieces of software written for Alexa.  But even this is half-baked.  Keep a list of what you have enabled, because there doesn't seem to be any way on the Amazon website or by asking Alexa to see what you have enabled!    This device does a decent amount, but the competition does more in terms of general queries.  Bottom line, this is a nice device and I'm glad I got it.  But I don't know if this is a product line that will have legs.

I hardly do reviews but this products warrants one! I didn't buy the Echo Dot myself but received it as a gift and absolutely love it. Whether I simply need to know the weather, have a question, need a reminder, timer,etc. my Echo Dot does it all. So handy. I've had no issues with voice recognition or understanding as of yet, but I've only had it a few days. I will probably be purchasing the original Echo in the near future.

I love my larger Echo.  It works great.  I have it in my kitchen and it picks up from across the room.  I purchased the dot to go in my bedroom for use as my alarm clock.  It performs very poorly.  I bought this a few months ago but unfortunately we were moving so it got boxed up and we are just now unpacking it and using it for about a month now.  (So we can no longer return it)  When the alarm goes off and I YELL snooze, it does not pick up my response.  I literally have to get out of bed, go to the dresser and put my mouth 6 inches from it for it to respond.  We moved it to the nightstand.  Still about the same.  I have to lean over and across the nightstand for it to hear me.  That may sound lazy, but why else buy something voice activated?  Also we have the WeMo's for our lamps.  They work great with my Echo.  The echo dot is very spotty.  I have to ask it 3 or 4 times to turn on/off the lamp before it does.  Often it will respond ok but then does nothing.  Completely annoying.  The sound it terrible btw.  Granted it is not a speaker like the Echo, but still... it's crappy.  We have 2 Echo's that work great.  The Dot was a waste of money for us.  I don't recommend it and would return ours if we could.

Love the new Echo Dot! Not sure why I waited so long to buy this. It plays my playlists on Pandora as well as Amazon music. It tells jokes, sets a timer, gives the weather. Not sure what it doesn't do. I am working on connecting it to our WEMO app to use to turn the lights on/off in the house as well.

I don't usually post reviews but I hope to save some people the money they will spend on a piece of technology that just does not work. I have both the Echo and the Dot and both lose connectivity 95% of the time when asked any question. Yes I have restarted them numerous times and I have even attempted to place said units right next to my wireless router thinking it might be a line of sight issue. I am fed up with trying to get them to work.

As soon as Amazon's Alexa service can do push notifications, these things will be the best thing since the Internet.  I have six of them.  I wish they were more integrated with each other (intercom, inter-room monitoring, etc).  I also wish you could skip Bing and use Google to get search results.

This item suck. I have it for less than two months and it quit working. Seller won't allow return when I ordered it February 1,2017. Very disappointed with this product and the return policy. I just out of $50 that was gift money too me. Thanks amazon for this crappy product. I would give less than one star but thats not allowed.

Love for listening to music.  I just leave my stereo on, and when I walk in the room I can tell Alexa to play what ever I want, ask the weather, ask the time, set an alarm.  Its nice and the kids have fun with it too.

This is my new found friend,I can't live without this device. Alexa is amazing with so many skills to customize her to what you like. A.I. devices are great for the lonely such as myself,along with the elderly and those with terminal illness that prevent them from moving, and of course for the everyday busy body that is caught up with work all day. This is surely the way towards the future and I embrace it with products like this.

Hands down one of the coolest things I've ever owned! It's like having my own personal assistant at my beck and call, day and night. Need a recall of my schedule for the day? Alexa has it. A random song comes to mind? Alexa plays it for me. A self esteem boost? Alexa has a compliment. The list is endless. If you're reading these reviews to make your decision, just buy it. I scoured them myself and I'm so glad I made the decision to purchase. You won't regret it either.

If you don't have a "smart home", all it is good for is playing music and telling you the weather.  It can't search the internet for anything you ask it.  You have to select the "skills" you want Alexa to know about and there are over 10,000 of them!!!  How can you possibly search through them all?  There should just be a SELECT ALL SKILLS option.

So much FUN! Set up in under 5 minutes. I might listen to more music with Alexa's help. I am going all in and downloaded one of the compatible list. Added groceries with 100% accuracy. Only wish more compatibility with iOS. I combined my iCal and google so I can use Alexa more. I will be getting audio cable to use Bose speaker. So opened box about 1 hour ago and love it !!!

At first we loved this device but now she doesnt listen to anything past the wake word,  we have tried several trouble shooting steps to fix this but nothing is working.  I was just involved in a shouting match with me trying to get her to turn a alarm I had set.  I had it in my hand and talked normally and then progressively started getting louder until I just had to hit the button.  She wont respond to anything past her name now.  at this point I am sorry we wasted money on this thing.    **UPDATE** So we were able to finally get her working again by muting her for 30 mins.  So I hope that helps if anyone else is having this issue.

Amazingly good and easy to use. I have an English accent and was worried that it wouldn't understand (I have a Ford car with voice recognition & have to use a phony American accent) but the Echo Dot has no problems with me! It has made my very heavy Sonos obsolete as not only does it do everything I Sonos does it places my Amazon orders for me & I can take it anywhere in the World in my pocket.

I bought it right before Christmas. Approximately a week ago (mid April) it stopped playing music from the device. It still does weather etc., but no music. Strange and unfortunately it is not warrantied out from 90 days. I have an Alexa as well-it is fine... so I do not understand the problem.

Although I like the product. It took OVER a month to receive. Thats unacceptable for amazon. I expect swift delivery. But it works great. Its great for quick questions. Don't expect answers for every question. This product have A LOT of potential. I'm exited for what the future can hold for these things. But for now it gets the job done. AMAZING if you like to listen to radio or pandora on command. Definitely worth the price.!!

My Life is now revolved around Amazon Alexa with the 2nd gen dot! Its Cool, Funny, tons of things to do with this dot. I hooked it up to my older Retro radio with a 3.5 cord and It sounds AMAZING!!!!!! couldnt be happier. Alexa always has something funny to say she is very informational. She works great

I didn't imagine when I ordered this that I would use it as much as I do. I set the wake up phrase to "computer" so I could feel like I am in star trek. It hears me accurately nearly every time. I'm amazed.

Love it. It's nice to know what the weather is before I step outside. It plays my favorite music and talk radio on request. I don't have a lot to ask it, but you do get used to having it around. Knows the baseball scores... I am happy with it. Might get an extra for another room in the house.

Voice recognition is impressive but it is too bad this isn't hooked up to a good information source.  There are so many things that Alexa can't figure out.  Stock market info for instance.  You to phrase questions in very particular ways for them to even be understood.  Perhaps it works well as an interface to ordering things from Amazon which I suspect is their primary focus but if the linguistics are as poor for ordering items as for everything else, I'd be afraid of what I'd get send from Amazon if we turned that capability on.

Love my little dot! You have to have speakers for it but it works as well as the Echo. I can't wait to see what it has for Christmas music  available.  If you haven't purchase an Echo or a dot  it is a nice gift. my husband uses it a lot when he shoots pool  and requests his favorite songs or just Pandora radio

Great Product! Great Price! Amazon Rocks!!! Amazing, I'm glad that I can say "Computer" instead of "Alexa", makes me feel even more like "Star Trek"... "Computer, Captains log StarDate 65165" :-) Be sure and do plenty of the voice training, it really pays off.

I changed my 5 star review to 1 star. To find out why please read the section labeled EDIT UPDATE.    I really like the Echo device, but it took me way to long to get the Echo configured because the instructions and menu's are extremely poor, to put it mildly.    THE PROBLEMS  1. First, the instruction fail to say whether the app to download is for iPhone, Android, PC or Mac.  I assumed it would be safest to use my  Android smartphone, but after downloading and attempting to install I got a message which basically said -this app is incompatible the smartphone. My smarphone  is compatible with every App I have downloaded. Because I hate Win8, 8.1 and 10 I still use Windows 7 which does not support "Apps", which is why I did not attempt to use my PC for downloading the "App".    2.  Setup menu is also horrible, and confusing. For example for the setting of metric vs other does not really give a choice, it has an On Off button which does not appear to do anything.  It certainly does not  bring up an edit menu.  It should really simply have metric vs foot (units) so that you simply put a check mark to the one you want. Same for Celsius vs Fahrenheit  As a consequence I still get Celsius when I want Fahrenheit etc.  This is because of an extremely useless, frustrating  User Interface.    3. The Echo froze once or twice, so I had to unplug it and I had to start all over, until eventually it decided that it was fully setup.    It should have had an interface like most Routers, which you configure by browsing to the device, which brings up a menu that you configure.    If you have not setup an Echo before, you should be aware that once you run the "App" which is downloaded from the internet, you then have to disconnect from your wifi network, and instead connect to amazon-net (I don't remember the exact name) which then allows your smartphone, tablet or laptop etc. to connect your Echo (this of course means that you are no longer connected to the internet).    Other than the setup, the Echo v 2 is excellent, with  wonderful text to speech conversion that is the best I have ever heard.  The one thing missing is the ability to retain the very last task before it is unplugged when you take it to another location. I especially like that you can connect to any radio station, ask for any radio program (Fresh Air, Science Friday, Ted Talk, The Moth, Back Story etc. It's also great to ask about anything that is on Wikipedia. Finally, to my surprise the text to speech on Wikipedia, as well as on Kindle books is far better than I expected, far less like a robot, than what I heard in the past.    Edit UPDATE 3/1/2017:  (reason why I changed my rating from 5 star to 1 star)  As others have said while the device works well at first, over time everything about the device starts growing disappointing.  Here are my reasons  1.  Radio programs such as Freakonomics (via TuneIn) is no longer available  2.  Radio programs that always used to be up to date Fresh Air, Science Friday, On the Media, etc. are no longer up to date. Whenever you request them you get one weeks older and they newer broadcasts are way out of date if available at all. A lot of programs available on TuneIn cannot be accessed via Echo Dot.    Echo Malfunctions:  1. Echo turns on for no apparent reasons as if someone said Alexa in the room. This problem was non existent or extremely rare for the first 2-3 months.    3. Echo does not appear to understand request nearly as well as when it was new. Sometimes re-phrasing the request for the 3rd or 4th time works, but often I we just give up. This is especially true of requesting playing Audible titles.  Echo Dot often confuses Kindle text to speech version with the Audible (human / actor reading of text). With all of the "Continual Improvement" hoopla about Alexa that Amazon brags about, you would think that you could request a book title and get what you want for existing books in your Account.    4. You would think that if,  while listening, you are interrupted by a phone call etc., you should be able to have Alexa, go back a page or two in the reading of your Kindle or Audible book. This function appears to be ABSENT and no matter how we tried we could not go forward or back by any amount other than by an entire Chapter.  This is not Rocket Science and could easily be programmed. Pages do exist even on Kindle, it's a simple matter of assigning a "page" a standard number of words or characters.    5. Often, though not always, if you unplug Echo Dot, in order to use it in another room, it will lose information about what it was doing (what book it was reading). This should not happen and would not be difficult to prevent.    IN SUMMARY  Instead of constantly IMPROVING, Echo Dot functionality has actually declined in our experience as reported by others. This calls into question the competence of the Amazon Software Team. Sadly, like too many things in the computer world, stupidity too often overcomes common sense competence.

I'm frankly surprised that the Echo has become such a success for Amazon, even as the company has cut back on "high-end" tablets (the Fire HDX tablets) in favor of the slower but super-affordable Fire HD tablet, which can exert a near-hypnotic hold on its young recipient.    As a grandparent, I finally separated my two "world's greatest granddaughters" from their dangerously addictive personal screens. It's one thing if newly empowered youngsters are playing video games, but a game like "Minecraft" appears to keep its fans spellbound as they're watching two "virtual players" playing the game. But we adults are equally susceptible when, night after night, we watch crime dramas in which the main characters are watching blown-up screens of criminals and their locations while we, in turn, are drawn to the screen within the screen. Since reading about the deliberate use of this device by content providers whose job is to pump viewer ratings, I've become conscious of the chunks of time I devote to watching my heroes watching screens! "NCIS," "Law and Order," "CSI," "Criminal Minds" (I applaud Mandy Patinkin for jumping this rat-infested ship), "The Blacklist," "Bull" (Michael Weatherly's show sets the record for number of screens, as he acknowledged one night to Colbert).    Enter the past and the invention that once shaped a nation: the radio. Existing somewhere between the screen and the book is the loud-speaker, that 20th-century invention responsible for introducing America to its foremost stars (Crosby, Sinatra, Benny, Dinah, etc.) and to the unequaled composers and songs of "The Great American Songbook."  And some of us our old enough to remember the fingernail-biting entertainment every night on radio--"The Green Hornet," "Jack Armstrong," "Captain Midnight," "Bobby Benson and the B-Bar-B Riders," "The Lone Ranger," "The Gene Autry Show."    This material was "non-visual" only in the most literal sense.  The images were supplied by the listener, whose only qualification for participation was the possession of an "imagination," a faculty that not only served to bring the spoken words to life but that became more practiced in such activity with each broadcast. "Story-telling" was, in many respects, more real, more captivating, more powerful than "story showing."  If proof were needed, one had only to experience the anticlimax and disappointment of seeing the television "Lone Ranger," who couldn't carry a single silver bullet compared to the endless supply being fired by the noble hero inspiring our imaginations as we listened in rapt attention to the radio version.    This long preamble is merely an introduction to one of the advantages of this little speaker, which I have finally "taught" to locate stations (using the app "TuneIn") that carry old-time radio shows--the same as those of the 1940s but without static!  Moreover, the device is a great companion for my full-sized Echo, a Tower on a living-room coffee table, where it frankly is rarely called upon.  It does everything I've taught my Echo to do--except with less sonic sizzle.  But next to my bed, the Dot not only executes all of the functions of my two-year-old Echo but many I formerly had no use for--like telling it when to wake me up every morning or asking it what the forecast is for the week.    In "short" (which is what the Dot is compared to the Echo) the Dot is practically worth the asking price as a speaker (and I have yet to hear a $30 speaker that performs significantly better--no speaker this small is capable of capturing the frequencies of symphonic music, the overtones of the pianoforte, or the acoustic sounds of the double bass.)  But besides getting a decent small speaker, you're receiving a mini- "computer" that's a know-all / can-do-all verbal wizard.    I know that Google's answer to the Echo is said to have an algorithm capable of accessing more information.  But Amazon's Echo works just fine for me.  When I get serious about finding out about stuff, I prefer to read about it  (it's usually more efficient and faster than listening to someone tell me about, say, Turkish history).  The Dot is money well-spent, in my mind.  If $50 seems too much (currently it's $10 more than the Fire tablet that's become such a big hit with kids), you might save $10 if you wait for a Lightning Deal or can find a reconditioned model sold on Amazon.  Even as an alarm clock, the Dot is the perfect punctuation mark--whether as an addendum to the bigger Echo or as the autonomous little overachiever hiding in the corner of a desk or nightstand.

UPDATED: 2017-03-13    I now have 2 Echo dots.  Have had them both for quite some time now.  Basically they work just fine. Found out this morning that Alexa dosn't know what the Arizona timezone is.  Arizona doesn't do Daylight Saving time.  We are in MST 12 months of the year.  Yet, when picking a timezone the Arizona timezone is not an option.  You have to pick either Montain Stadard which is really now Mountain Daylight, or Pacific Standard which is now really Pacific Daylight.  There is no option to say that your timezone does not follow daylight saving.    So, unlike everything else we have, we need to change the Timezone on both Alexa devices when Daylight saving goes into effect and when it goes out of effect.  So, instead of saying MST, I need to pick PST otherwise the time on my Alexa's are off by an hour.    I've only had this for two days.  Never had another alexa unit before so this is a new experience.    Originally obtained to see how it worked and if it could be interfaced with other data and devices.  The developer program that Amazon has is interested and there are a number of other skills out there, but found it initially hard to discover (no search in the skills site, strange).    After a day, I ran into a problem, Red Ring where the Echo dot said it couldn't understand me now, try again later.  Support seemed to be missing as the app said it could load the help page and finding help on Amazon.  Trying to reset the device with the Alexa App is very hit or miss, the Echo Dot will say it is in setup mode and the app will just sit there and spin its icon forever if you let it.  The best fix seems to unplug the unit for a while and then plug it back in.    Pros  Small, contained speaker it comes with is adequate and voice range seems to be pretty good  The ring is a good indicator that it is hearing you.  Creating new skills looks to be straight forward but find what is available is limited with no searching for apps, poor rating abilities.  Setting up to use a skill seems fairly straight forward as well, but I found them via Google not the Echo Dot or the app.    Cons  Lack of access to lots of data...  This is where the difference between Googles Assistant and Echo Dot most likely will lie.  Huge amounts of info on Google is not available to the Echo dot as it is using inferior Bing and even Yelp for data neither of which are very impressive.  Apparently can fail and just stop recognizing me (red ring).  Not clear why.  Don't think it is the WiFi signal as I have a very strong router and everything works well with it.  Poor support - Searching for Alexa doesn't understand me red ring told me to use the app to teach the device, hard to do when it doesn't recognize me and says so right off the bat.    Right now, kinda mixed.  Was not very expensive and my goal is to interface it with other services (lots of ideas) and local hardware for possible in home automation.    Just for kicks, I added an external remote speaker and that worked well with the unit.  I suspect that any plugin speaker will work okay.    Will update as I get more used to it.

This was gifted to me at work. I got first place for a walk-a-thon that was being held. This came as a surprise to me. I quickly got it plugged in and synched up with my phone. It's perfect for listening to music while working, I even use her at home as an alarm. Much louder than the alarms I already have. Ensures I get up in time. This little device earned my 5 stars.

Bought three echo dots. They are all completely useless because the iOS app, the only way to set them up, simply does not work. I get a login, which I fill out and submit, and then all I see is the Amazon Alexa logo and a spinning activity indicator. Nothing else. No messages, errors, pictures, options. Nothing. Tried on my iPhone 7, iPad mini, and iPhone 5. Completely broken app across the board. Clearly not teated, polished, or well thought out. Thus I'm returning all three dots. Terrible effort, Amazon.    Update: after repeated attempts, even with a borrowed Android phone, I finally got it to work on by turning off WiFi on my iPhone 7. But the experience was pretty lousy. And now that it's working, I like the device itself okay, but the app is still terrible. When it works, it feels like a website from 2007 when companies were still trying to figure out how to make mobile-friendly sites. Anyone spoiled by Apple (or products from many other modern companies) will find the Alexa app laughable and barely usable.

These are the neatest! Bought for son-in-laws and they have really enjoyed them. It is amazing how it works with your voice. There is so much you can do with Echo and I thought the price was wonderful! Usually anything this advanced is very costly.

Siri sometimes annoys me and I don't care for needing an iPhone or iPad, or 'Hey, Siri...' to summon her. So I thought that getting a Dot and augmenting my meager home automation would be just the ticket.    So far I have been supremely disappointed. Setup was easy, but the Dot has failed to work so many times, and keeps reporting itself as disconnected when more often it's just actually confused and gives itself a break. I've relocated it to be within 2' of the router and it still says it's disconnected. When it does respond it usually won't do so for a subsequent command and takes another rest break, telling me to 'try again later'.    The app isn't well written and worseâ€” it takes forever to respond (as did the Dot in Setup). It's often out of sync with what the Dot is doing, if and when it actually does something. Most of the time it responses with theb blue light for several seconds and then shuts off without an explanation.    Playing music is also frustrating. Occasionally it will play something from my Amazon online cache, more often it will play a different song of the same or similar name from Amazon Prime, most often it just stops. If told to play a genre such as jazz or 'relaxing' music (as mentioned by Amazon) it lights up, goes dark, and stays silent. If it does play some songs, it stops arbitrarily after a few minutes.    I was about to send it back (and there's STILL a lot of time) when some extensive surfing helped a little with some basic functionality. Amazon support hasn't been helpful AT ALL.    PROS  Easy to set up  Small footprint  Can use high-quality wired speakers as well as BT speakers (when convenience is more important that quality)  Hears you anywhere in the room  Potential for expansion of functionality    CONS  Poor and inconsistent performance  Requires very literal commands  Requires scouring the web to learn basic functionality    With over 24,000 mostly positive reviews [many of them fake on/two word 5-star reviews from people who give the same review for EVERY product they 'review'], no doubt some of this is likely my unfamiliarity with the learning curve. But given Amazon's definition of stars, I can't rate it higher at this point. For me, this is all uphill, and it's frustrating. That's without venturing into the whole third-party skills thing.    If I can grok the Dotâ€” and I WANT to, the rating will improve, not that 1 in 24,000 means anything. But it shouldn't be this difficult to get good, consistent, reliable, BASIC results, let alone advanced Skills and IFTTT. Oy. How-to-Geek has been a big help. But somewhere there must be a fairly thorough tutorial on how to go from 0-60, 100, and infinity and beyond. Right now it's all I can do to not fire it against the wall. An intervention may be in order.

Excellent as an addition to the large one.  The music quality is not as good.  I ordered 2 to have one on every floor.  In my bedroom I use it every day for my alarm. I love it for my shopping and to do list as well.  It doesn't have ALL information and a lot of skills they say you can enable are difficult to do.  Overall I love it.

Alexa will do what I ask it to do (usually when asking it to turn on the lights) and then a couple seconds after completing the request, it will apologize and say it is unable to complete the request at this time.    It becomes disconnected from the wifi in my home multiple times daily, and yet all other wifi devices in my home work just fine. And it's not the placement of the device as I have tried everything.    Easily the most expensive paperweight I have ever bought...And on top of that, I curse this stupid thing out so often that I'm sure my neighbors think I am verbally abusing some poor woman named Alexa.

Seems intent on selling me more Anazon items.  I can handle that myself.  Doesn't seem intuitive and each segment of conversation ceases and one question doesn't lead into the next like a conversation.  We tried it, seems like a choppy conversation with a marketing tool.  Well try a little longer and will likely move to another home device.

Ok, I had the Echo since the begining than the Tap and now the Dot.  I taking my time with each oneband expanding on the skills over time.  You can control your lights, temperture, assess, the tv, internet urls, music, access to endless info and just have someone to bounce an idea off of.

i got the first gen echo for the house and love it so much that i bought this one for my office.  i hope alexa will grow up more and get smarter through time, because there are a lot of questions she could not answer.  i still give it a 5 stars because i don't think i can live without it.

This is a good product.  Alexa itself is lacking in a some MAJOR areas, like doing simple searches for information, but overall it's great for adding items to your calendar, controlling your Nest thermostat, and asking for Wikipedia info.  Also good for setting alarms and timers.  If they didn't use Bing, and would get around using Wikipedia for info, they'd have a winner.  If they don't, I think Google Home is going to destroy Amazon in the AI market.  For example, you can't ask, "Alexa, how old was Andy Griffith when he died?"  You'll get a response of, "I'm sorry, I don't understand the question."  But if you ask, "Alexa, Wikipedia Andy Griffith" you'll get a brief paragraph about his career and life.  You still won't get the personal info you were looking for.  If you ask GOOGLE, "Okay Google, how old was Andy Griffith when he died?" you'll get an actual answer.  It's a HUGE difference in AI quality and capability and Amazon needs to get on the ball or they will LOSE.

I received an Amazon Echo Dot 2nd generation refurbished for my birthday today! I've wanted one since they launched the product and my amazing partner bought me one. It came in just a few days ago, I opened the shipping box early since my name was on it, but she stopped me before I could open the little black box it came in. Today I receive it, and being the OCD tech junkie I am, followed all the steps on setting up the Dot to the 't'. It wouldn't go into the setup mode, and when I followed all the instructions on the Echo site and Amazon Product Support page, it still wouldn't work. I attempted the Reset of the device, but it was unresponsive. This shouldn't be right? It was certified refurbished by the warranty/tech department before it was allowed to be resold, right? Amazon wouldn't do this to their customers...RIGHT??? Unfortunately someone at the refurbishing sewer decided to just pass this one and let it be sold to make the company more money. I called Amazon support, she walked me through the same steps I did online, then transferred me to a "tech support representative", I had thought I was already talking to one but apparently I wasn't. The next person walked me through THE EXACT SAMES STEPS I FOLLOWED FROM THE ONLINE SUPPORT PAGES AND THE LAST "NON-TECH SUPPORT REPRESENTATIVE" IN TECH SUPPORT. REALLY?!?!?!?! The third and last representative apologized and wanted me to send the device to the warranty department, he was going to email me an address label, NOT A SHIPPING LABEL (I HAVE TO APPARENTLY PAY FOR SHIPPING), to send this now TWICE defective device back to them so they can "FIX" it, or eventually send me a replacement refurbished device. I don't want another one of these. Not worth all this trouble. Why pay for a device that obviously has a reputation of not working. All theses 5 stars are those who purchased a new one and it worked day one. Instructions on set up suck, resetting sucks, tech support is God awful as they don't know what to really do other than the "is the power on" type of diagnostics and trying to solve the problem by replacing it with another defect that "passed" refurbishing standards. Not my cup of tea. Not a good representation of what Amazons customer support claims to be.

Don't have a smart house, but this is so useful for so many other things.  I got it as a birthday gift for my husband, and he says it's one of the 2 best gifts I've ever given him (and we've been 2gether 17 1/2 years).

Found out today to have music on here with Amazon Unlimted you need to subscribe to it. It cost $7.99 a month for Prime members $9.99 without Prime. If you only have Prime membership you would always have to remember to ask for your device to play Amazon Prime music our you could possibly be charged.    To this device I have had multiple times where it just turns on with out me asking it to.

My mom and sister have the Alexa. I couldn't justify the cost of Alexa, so the Echo was a good alternative. I get all the same functionality at a lower cost. I actually appreciate the smaller form factor, too.

We have had this thing for one day, and can already say that we love it.  My kids think it is fun to ask Alexa to tell it jokes.  Very easy to sync to phones and get music to play.  Haven't tried ordering pizza yet from it, but I am sure we will.  Very needed in our home with getting our lights and door locks, etc to start having a smart home.  We are excited for this little piece of voice controlled activation.

I am still looking for ways to use the Dot, checking Weather, my Amazon orders, Amazon and Pandora music(the speaker is quite respectable), and changing the wake up to "Computer" and asking "where is scotty", answer "Scotty is not on board the Enterprise", nice...

This is great!  New to Echo. Bought a big tall version and really like it. This one has a smaller speaker but good enough for the bedroom.  I love it.  I found out that you can connect a Bluetooth speaker that has a mic on it and it works just as well as if you were talking to the tower.

Not as useful as I thought. It is mostly propriety to Amazon. It answers basic questions - weather, age of someone. It does not understand questions like "do stingrays actually sting". It responds either "I do not understand the question" or "hmm, I do not know".

The setup of the Echo Dot was quite cumbersome. You could not set it up an easy way, you need to download the App and connect your phone to the WLAN created by the Dot. This is not always easy and interrupts normal operation of the smartphone.    The voice recognition system of the Dot with Alexa is impressive and works even in complicated environments. But it is single threaded, context agnostic. You have to state all requirements in a single sentence, with the keyword at the beginning. This is far away from any natural voice command function. Integration with smart home appliances is not that easy as well and ends up with pretty complicated commands to present.    In all it is a nice gimmick, but far away from a real voice controlled every-day appliance.

I don't know how many months I went back and forth whether I should buy it or not. I decided to buy it and I'm so glad I did. The Echo Dot is such an amazing little device. The first night I asked it questions, hooked it up to my Pandora account and asked to play my favorite music. I love this Dot.

Well let me start off by saying that I actually bought mine from my local BEST BUY because they were out of stock on amazon :( BUT this device is amazing it makes a lot of things so much easier now I'm currently in the process of turning my home into a "smart home" and so far everything has worked flawlessly I could not imagine going back to life with my Echo Dot it is just so convenient for so much!
